review: *Seven Summer Weekends* may not be officially part of a series, but it continues the narrative of the author’s previous novel, *On Fire Island*. A central character from the first book returns, along with several secondary characters, enriching the experience for readers familiar with the earlier story. However, the novel stands on its own, and while reading both books in order enhances the connection to the characters, it is not necessary. The plot follows Addison Irwin, who, after a decade in advertising, finds herself unemployed and inheriting her late aunt’s estate on Fire Island. The inheritance comes with stipulations requiring her to spend the summer there before deciding whether to sell. As Addison immerses herself in the island’s close-knit community, she finds her neighbor Ben to be a source of frustration.

The novel shines in its development of central characters Addison and Ben, making them both relatable and engaging. Their evolving relationship and personal growth kept me thoroughly invested in the story.
The author's writing style is consistently charming and emotionally resonant. Having finished this book, I am eager to explore more of her work in the future.
conclusion: *Seven Summer Weekends* is a delightful contemporary romance that builds on the charm of its predecessor while standing strong on its own. Though it lacks some of the unique elements of *On Fire Island*, it offers a more focused and engaging romance that left me eager to read more from the author.

review: The ending felt overly perfect and rushed, lacking a sense of finality. It wrapped up too quickly and anticlimactically. Although it's a rom-com with a happy ending, their relationship didn't resonate with me emotionally as I had hoped when they first met.

The side characters, including Addison’s friends, parents, and those who assisted her at the beach house, felt somewhat superficial. I would have appreciated a deeper exploration of Gicky’s friends and their genuine influence on Addison. A few additional chapters showcasing their time together could have added emotional depth to the story.

The author’s eloquence captivated me, and I found myself eagerly absorbing many passages. However, I struggled with the frequent shifts in perspective. Characters would often take over as narrators for a chapter before returning to Addison’s point of view, and their sections lacked distinctiveness, making it difficult to recognize the changes in perspective.

I enjoyed the setting and atmosphere of Fire Island. After my recent trip to New York, I found myself longing for that vibe. While it wasn't exactly the same, it offered a pleasant and relaxing beach read.

I appreciated the exploration of grief, both in terms of losing a loved one and the challenge of moving forward. This added significant depth to the narrative. Ben, as the love interest, intrigued me; it's rare to see such a loving husband depicted in this genre, especially beyond the leads' relationship.

While reading this book, I experienced a mix of enjoyment and frustration. There were moments that captivated me, but others that pulled me out of the narrative. I struggled to connect with the characters, particularly Addison and Ben. At 35, Addison felt surprisingly immature, and Ben's tendency to miscommunicate and avoid confronting issues was equally off-putting.
conclusion: Overall, this book had moments of enjoyment and beautiful writing, but it was hindered by inconsistent pacing, underdeveloped characters, and a rushed ending. review: "Seven Summer Weekends" follows Addison, who finds herself adrift after being fired from her advertising job due to a Zoom mishap. When she inherits her aunt's cottage on Fire Island, she encounters her neighbor Ben on a ferry, sparking an initial flirtation. However, Addison soon decides she can't stand him. As she discovers Ben is a famous writer grappling with profound loss, their relationship transforms into a heartfelt love story. Over the course of seven weeks, the novel weaves together moments of joy and sorrow, showcasing the complexities of love and friendship. Addison's best friends arrive just when she needs them most, emphasizing the importance of camaraderie and adding layers of romance to the narrative.

As a long-time fan of this author, I found *Seven Summer Weekends* enjoyable, though it doesn't quite surpass my favorite, *Eliza Starts a Rumor*. The novel cleverly references last year's hit, *On Fire Island*, where Ben, a central character in *Seven Summer Weekends*, was introduced. In *On Fire Island*, we learn about Ben's journey through his wife's illness and death. In this new installment, Ben is portrayed as the author of *On Fire Island*, creating an intriguing connection between his fictional readers and the author's audience, both reflecting on his grief. While *Seven Summer Weekends* can stand alone, I recommend reading *On Fire Island* first for a deeper understanding of Ben's character.
In the Afterword, the author reveals her intention to write a romcom; however, I found it lacking in humor. This absence of comedy didn't bother me, as I generally prefer more serious narratives.
conclusion: Seven Summer Weekends is a well-written, engaging novel that blends romance, friendship, and personal growth. While it didn't meet my expectations as a romcom, its serious tone and emotional depth made it an enjoyable read. Fans of the author will appreciate the connections to the previous work, *On Fire Island*, though this book stands well on its own.
